title: The Coughing Quarter
description: A cluster of respiratory illness cases has appeared in the Lower Ward — seventeen people in four adjacent streets all presenting the same dry cough and morning fever within a single week. Medical Quarter Director Sela believes this is environmental rather than contagious. She needs someone to identify the source.

turns.narrative: All seventeen cases live or work within two hundred metres of each other. The illness isn't spreading beyond that radius, which confirms Director Sela's hypothesis: environmental exposure. Dust Analyst Kem suggests checking the neighbourhood's air quality and building conditions.
turns.choice_a: Inspect the buildings in the affected radius for any new construction or industrial activity
turns.consequence_a: You find that a warehouse conversion project began ten days ago — seven days before the first cases. The conversion disturbed forty years of accumulated dust and old stone plaster.
turns.choice_b: Collect air samples in the affected streets at different times of day
turns.consequence_b: Morning samples are dramatically higher in fine particulate matter than afternoon. The source is something that disperses during early morning temperature changes.

turns.narrative: Investigation confirms the warehouse conversion is releasing Settled Quarry Dust — fine silica particles from the original construction period that accumulate in old walls. It's not toxic in small amounts but at this concentration it causes respiratory irritation.
turns.choice_a: Order the construction company to halt work immediately pending dust abatement
turns.consequence_a: The site supervisor is resistant but backs down when you invoke Ward public health authority.
turns.choice_b: Work with Kem to arrange free particle masks for all affected residents while the source is addressed
turns.consequence_b: Kem distributes masks to all seventeen affected households within two hours. Symptoms begin improving.

turns.narrative: Director Sela wants the conversion project to comply with dust safety standards before resuming.
turns.choice_a: Draft a compliance checklist for the construction company to meet before work resumes
turns.consequence_a: The checklist is submitted to the Ward Authority. Construction resumes ten days later with proper dust suppression.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the Medical Quarter establish a formal Environmental Illness Investigation protocol
turns.consequence_b: Sela approves. A new Environmental Illness Protocol is formally adopted by the Medical Quarter.

construction_halted.description: Construction halted. Dust abatement required before resuming.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Construction halted. Dust abatement required before resuming.
